bibl.title: Letter from G.W. McCoy to A.M. Stimson, June 23, 1923

div1.p: McCoy comments on Pothier's results concerning the Pfeiffer phenomenon and yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from G.W. McCoy to A.M. Stimson, June 23, 1923
div1.opener:
Yellow Fever:
Hygienic Laboratory
CA--MAN
SR
June 23, 1923.
div1.p:
The attached letter from Dr. Pothier at Baranquilla
addressed to Dr. J.H. White and referred to Dr. R.H. Carter
by Miss Florence M. Read of the International Health
Board, by Dr. Carter referred to the Division of
Scientific Research, is respectfully returned to the
Surgeon General, for the attention of Assistant Surgeon
General A.M. Stimson, with memorandum prepared by
Passed Assistant Surgeon C. Armstrong in re cases of
yellow fever in Bucamaranga:

Noguchi (1) and Noguchi and Klinger (2) using cultures of
Leptospira icteroides have found the Pfeiffer phenomenon
positive with sera of yellow fever convalescents (7th day
to some months after onset of attack) in from 85 to 100%
of cases. Noguchi (3) also secured positive agglutniation
reactions using immune sera and the same organism in a titer
of 1:5.

The results reported by Dr. Pothier may therefore be signifi-
cant; however, in the absence of an exact description of
his methods, and especially the entire absence of any mention
of proper control tests, using the serum of non-immune yellow
fever subjects (normal and suffering with ailments other than
yellow fever) carried out under identical conditions, would
seem to place the results in the category of indefinite but
rather suggestive reactions.

The negative results in one case using the Pfeiffer phenomenon
and L. icterohaemorrhagica is not a proper control with
this organism, since the proportion of serum to culture was
1:50 instead of 1:1 as used with L. icteroides.
div1.closer:
G.W. McCoy,
Director. CA.
REFERENCES:
(1) Noguchi, H.: Jrn. Exp. Med. XXX, 9. 1919.
(2) Noguchi and Klinger, Jrn. Exp. Med. XXXII, 627, 1920
(3) Noguchi, Jrn. Exp. Med. XXXi, 135, 1920.
